description.html: The :active CSS pseudo-class represents an element (such as a button) that is being activated by the user. When using a mouse, "activation" typically starts when the user presses down the primary mouse button.
description.text: The :active CSS pseudo-class represents an element (such as a button) that is being activated by the user. When using a mouse, "activation" typically starts when the user presses down the primary mouse button.

description.html: The :any-link CSS pseudo-class selector represents an element that acts as the source anchor of a hyperlink, independent of whether it has been visited. In other words, it matches every <a>, <area>, or <link> element that has an href attribute. Thus, it matches all elements that match :link or :visited.
description.text: The :any-link CSS pseudo-class selector represents an element that acts as the source anchor of a hyperlink, independent of whether it has been visited. In other words, it matches every <a>, <area>, or <link> element that has an href attribute. Thus, it matches all elements that match :link or :visited.

description.html: The :blank CSS pseudo-class selects empty user input elements (eg. <input> or <textarea>).
description.text: The :blank CSS pseudo-class selects empty user input elements (eg. <input> or <textarea>).

description.html: The :checked CSS pseudo-class selector represents any radio (<input type="radio">), checkbox (<input type="checkbox">), or option (<option> in a <select>) element that is checked or toggled to an on state.
description.text: The :checked CSS pseudo-class selector represents any radio (<input type="radio">), checkbox (<input type="checkbox">), or option (<option> in a <select>) element that is checked or toggled to an on state.

description.html: The :default CSS pseudo-class selects form elements that are the default in a group of related elements.
description.text: The :default CSS pseudo-class selects form elements that are the default in a group of related elements.

description.html: The :defined CSS pseudo-class represents any element that has been defined. This includes any standard element built in to the browser, and custom elements that have been successfully defined (i.e. with the CustomElementRegistry.define() method).
description.text: The :defined CSS pseudo-class represents any element that has been defined. This includes any standard element built in to the browser, and custom elements that have been successfully defined (i.e. with the CustomElementRegistry.define() method).

description.html: The :dir() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on the directionality of the text contained in them.
description.text: The :dir() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on the directionality of the text contained in them.

description.html: The :disabled CSS pseudo-class represents any disabled element. An element is disabled if it can't be activated (selected, clicked on, typed into, etc.) or accept focus. The element also has an enabled state, in which it can be activated or accept focus.
description.text: The :disabled CSS pseudo-class represents any disabled element. An element is disabled if it can't be activated (selected, clicked on, typed into, etc.) or accept focus. The element also has an enabled state, in which it can be activated or accept focus.

description.html: The :empty CSS pseudo-class represents any element that has no children. Children can be either element nodes or text (including whitespace). Comments, processing instructions, and CSS content do not affect whether an element is considered empty.
description.text: The :empty CSS pseudo-class represents any element that has no children. Children can be either element nodes or text (including whitespace). Comments, processing instructions, and CSS content do not affect whether an element is considered empty.

description.html: The :enabled CSS pseudo-class represents any enabled element. An element is enabled if it can be activated (selected, clicked on, typed into, etc.) or accept focus. The element also has a disabled state, in which it can't be activated or accept focus.
description.text: The :enabled CSS pseudo-class represents any enabled element. An element is enabled if it can be activated (selected, clicked on, typed into, etc.) or accept focus. The element also has a disabled state, in which it can't be activated or accept focus.

description.html: The :first CSS pseudo-class, used with the  @page at-rule, represents the first page of a printed document. (See :first-child for general first element of a node.)
description.text: The :first CSS pseudo-class, used with the  @page at-rule, represents the first page of a printed document. (See :first-child for general first element of a node.)

description.html: The :first-child CSS pseudo-class represents the first element among a group of sibling elements.
description.text: The :first-child CSS pseudo-class represents the first element among a group of sibling elements.

description.html: The :first-of-type CSS pseudo-class represents the first element of its type among a group of sibling elements.
description.text: The :first-of-type CSS pseudo-class represents the first element of its type among a group of sibling elements.

description.html: The :fullscreen CSS pseudo-class matches every element which is currently in full-screen mode. If multiple elements have been put into full-screen mode, this selects them all.
description.text: The :fullscreen CSS pseudo-class matches every element which is currently in full-screen mode. If multiple elements have been put into full-screen mode, this selects them all.

description.html: The :focus CSS pseudo-class represents an element (such as a form input) that has received focus. It is generally triggered when the user clicks or taps on an element or selects it with the keyboard's "tab" key.
description.text: The :focus CSS pseudo-class represents an element (such as a form input) that has received focus. It is generally triggered when the user clicks or taps on an element or selects it with the keyboard's "tab" key.

description.html: The :focus-visible pseudo-class applies while an element matches the :focus pseudo-class and the UA (User Agent) determines via heuristics that the focus should be made evident on the element. (Many browsers show a “focus ring” by default in this case.)
description.text: The :focus-visible pseudo-class applies while an element matches the :focus pseudo-class and the UA (User Agent) determines via heuristics that the focus should be made evident on the element. (Many browsers show a “focus ring” by default in this case.)

description.html: The :focus-within CSS pseudo-class represents an element that has received focus or contains an element that has received focus. In other words, it represents an element that is itself matched by the :focus pseudo-class or has a descendant that is matched by :focus. (This includes descendants in shadow trees.)
description.text: The :focus-within CSS pseudo-class represents an element that has received focus or contains an element that has received focus. In other words, it represents an element that is itself matched by the :focus pseudo-class or has a descendant that is matched by :focus. (This includes descendants in shadow trees.)

description.html: The :has() pseudo-class takes a relative selector list as an argument. In earlier revisions of the CSS Selectors Level 4 specification, :has had a limitation that it can not be used within stylesheets; only with functions like document.querySelector() (because of performance concerns). This limitation is now removed because no browser has implemented it this way.
description.text: The :has() pseudo-class takes a relative selector list as an argument. In earlier revisions of the CSS Selectors Level 4 specification, :has had a limitation that it can not be used within stylesheets; only with functions like document.querySelector() (because of performance concerns). This limitation is now removed because no browser has implemented it this way.

description.html: The :host CSS pseudo-class selects the shadow host of the shadow DOM containing the CSS it is used inside — in other words, this allows you to select a custom element from inside its shadow DOM.
description.text: The :host CSS pseudo-class selects the shadow host of the shadow DOM containing the CSS it is used inside — in other words, this allows you to select a custom element from inside its shadow DOM.

description.html: The :host() CSS pseudo-class function selects the shadow host of the shadow DOM containing the CSS it is used inside (so you can select a custom element from inside its shadow DOM) — but only if the selector given as the function's parameter matches the shadow host.
description.text: The :host() CSS pseudo-class function selects the shadow host of the shadow DOM containing the CSS it is used inside (so you can select a custom element from inside its shadow DOM) — but only if the selector given as the function's parameter matches the shadow host.

description.html: The :host-context() CSS pseudo-class function selects the shadow host of the shadow DOM containing the CSS it is used inside (so you can select a custom element from inside its shadow DOM) — but only if the selector given as the function's parameter matches the shadow host's ancestor(s) in the place it sits inside the DOM hierarchy.
description.text: The :host-context() CSS pseudo-class function selects the shadow host of the shadow DOM containing the CSS it is used inside (so you can select a custom element from inside its shadow DOM) — but only if the selector given as the function's parameter matches the shadow host's ancestor(s) in the place it sits inside the DOM hierarchy.

description.html: The :hover CSS pseudo-class matches when the user interacts with an element with a pointing device, but does not necessarily activate it. It is generally triggered when the user hovers over an element with the cursor (mouse pointer).
description.text: The :hover CSS pseudo-class matches when the user interacts with an element with a pointing device, but does not necessarily activate it. It is generally triggered when the user hovers over an element with the cursor (mouse pointer).

description.html: The :indeterminate CSS pseudo-class represents any form element whose state is indeterminate.
description.text: The :indeterminate CSS pseudo-class represents any form element whose state is indeterminate.

description.html: The :in-range CSS pseudo-class represents an <input> element whose current value is within the range limits specified by the min and max attributes.
description.text: The :in-range CSS pseudo-class represents an <input> element whose current value is within the range limits specified by the min and max attributes.

description.html: The :invalid CSS pseudo-class represents any <input> or other <form> element whose contents fail to validate.
description.text: The :invalid CSS pseudo-class represents any <input> or other <form> element whose contents fail to validate.

description.html: The :is() CSS pseudo-class function takes a selector list as its argument, and selects any element that can be selected by one of the selectors in that list. This is useful for writing large selectors in a more compact form.
description.text: The :is() CSS pseudo-class function takes a selector list as its argument, and selects any element that can be selected by one of the selectors in that list. This is useful for writing large selectors in a more compact form.

description.html: The :lang() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on the language they are determined to be in.
description.text: The :lang() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on the language they are determined to be in.

description.html: The :last-child CSS pseudo-class represents the last element among a group of sibling elements.
description.text: The :last-child CSS pseudo-class represents the last element among a group of sibling elements.

description.html: The :last-of-type CSS pseudo-class represents the last element of its type among a group of sibling elements.
description.text: The :last-of-type CSS pseudo-class represents the last element of its type among a group of sibling elements.

description.html: The :left CSS pseudo-class, used with the @page at-rule, represents all left-hand pages of a printed document.
description.text: The :left CSS pseudo-class, used with the @page at-rule, represents all left-hand pages of a printed document.

description.html: The :link CSS pseudo-class represents an element that has not yet been visited. It matches every unvisited <a>, <area>, or <link> element that has an href attribute.
description.text: The :link CSS pseudo-class represents an element that has not yet been visited. It matches every unvisited <a>, <area>, or <link> element that has an href attribute.

description.html: The :not() CSS pseudo-class represents elements that do not match a list of selectors. Since it prevents specific items from being selected, it is known as the negation pseudo-class.
description.text: The :not() CSS pseudo-class represents elements that do not match a list of selectors. Since it prevents specific items from being selected, it is known as the negation pseudo-class.

description.html: The :nth-child() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on their position in a group of siblings.
description.text: The :nth-child() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on their position in a group of siblings.

description.html: The :nth-last-child() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on their position among a group of siblings, counting from the end.
description.text: The :nth-last-child() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on their position among a group of siblings, counting from the end.

description.html: The :nth-last-of-type() CSS pseudo-class matches elements of a given type, based on their position among a group of siblings, counting from the end.
description.text: The :nth-last-of-type() CSS pseudo-class matches elements of a given type, based on their position among a group of siblings, counting from the end.

description.html: The :nth-of-type() CSS pseudo-class matches elements of a given type (tag name), based on their position among a group of siblings.
description.text: The :nth-of-type() CSS pseudo-class matches elements of a given type (tag name), based on their position among a group of siblings.

description.html: The :only-child CSS pseudo-class represents an element without any siblings. This is the same as :first-child:last-child or :nth-child(1):nth-last-child(1), but with a lower specificity.
description.text: The :only-child CSS pseudo-class represents an element without any siblings. This is the same as :first-child:last-child or :nth-child(1):nth-last-child(1), but with a lower specificity.

description.html: The :only-of-type CSS pseudo-class represents an element that has no siblings of the same type.
description.text: The :only-of-type CSS pseudo-class represents an element that has no siblings of the same type.

description.html: The :optional CSS pseudo-class represents any <input>, <select>, or <textarea> element that does not have the required attribute set on it.
description.text: The :optional CSS pseudo-class represents any <input>, <select>, or <textarea> element that does not have the required attribute set on it.

description.html: The :out-of-range CSS pseudo-class represents an <input> element whose current value is outside the range limits specified by the min and max attributes.
description.text: The :out-of-range CSS pseudo-class represents an <input> element whose current value is outside the range limits specified by the min and max attributes.

description.html: The :placeholder-shown CSS pseudo-class represents any <input> or <textarea> element that is currently displaying placeholder text.
description.text: The :placeholder-shown CSS pseudo-class represents any <input> or <textarea> element that is currently displaying placeholder text.

description.html: The :read-only CSS pseudo-class represents an element (such as input or textarea) that is not editable by the user.
description.text: The :read-only CSS pseudo-class represents an element (such as input or textarea) that is not editable by the user.

description.html: The :read-write CSS pseudo-class represents an element (such as input or textarea) that is editable by the user.
description.text: The :read-write CSS pseudo-class represents an element (such as input or textarea) that is editable by the user.

description.html: The :required CSS pseudo-class represents any <input>, <select>, or <textarea> element that has the required attribute set on it.
description.text: The :required CSS pseudo-class represents any <input>, <select>, or <textarea> element that has the required attribute set on it.

description.html: The :right CSS pseudo-class, used with the @page at-rule, represents all right-hand pages of a printed document.
description.text: The :right CSS pseudo-class, used with the @page at-rule, represents all right-hand pages of a printed document.

description.html: The :root CSS pseudo-class matches the root element of a tree representing the document. In HTML, :root represents the <html> element and is identical to the selector html, except that its specificity is higher.
description.text: The :root CSS  pseudo-class matches the root element of a tree representing the document. In HTML, :root represents the <html> element and is identical to the selector html, except that its specificity is higher.

description.html: The :scope CSS pseudo-class represents elements that are a reference point for selectors to match against.
description.text: The :scope CSS pseudo-class represents elements that are a reference point for selectors to match against.

description.html: The :state CSS pseudo-class represents any custom element with the specified custom state in ElementInternals.states.
description.text: The :state CSS pseudo-class represents any custom element with the specified custom state in ElementInternals.states.

description.html: The :target CSS pseudo-class represents a unique element (the target element) with an id matching the URL's fragment.
description.text: The :target CSS pseudo-class represents a unique element (the target element) with an id matching the URL's fragment.

description.html: The :valid CSS pseudo-class represents any <input> or other <form> element whose contents validate successfully. This allows to easily make valid fields adopt an appearance that helps the user confirm that their data is formatted properly.
description.text: The :valid CSS pseudo-class represents any <input> or other <form> element whose contents validate successfully. This allows to easily make valid fields adopt an appearance that helps the user confirm that their data is formatted properly.

description.html: The :visited CSS pseudo-class represents links that the user has already visited. For privacy reasons, the styles that can be modified using this selector are very limited.
description.text: The :visited CSS pseudo-class represents links that the user has already visited. For privacy reasons, the styles that can be modified using this selector are very limited.

description.html: The :where() CSS pseudo-class function takes a selector list as its argument, and selects any element that can be selected by one of the selectors in that list.
description.text: The :where() CSS pseudo-class function takes a selector list as its argument, and selects any element that can be selected by one of the selectors in that list.
